articles.headline: Inflation Gives Signs of Slowing
articles.snippet: The latest report on consumer prices appears to support the Federal Reserve’s decision to halt its interest rate increases.
articles.abstract: The latest report on consumer prices appears to support the Federal Reserve’s decision to halt its interest rate increases.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government’s latest report on consumer prices, issued yesterday, suggests that inflation is slowing.

articles.headline: Peltz Is Seen With 2 Seats at Heinz
articles.snippet: Investor Nelson Peltz won seats on the board of the H. J. Heinz Company, setting up a showdown over its future.
articles.abstract: Investor Nelson Peltz won seats on the board of the H. J. Heinz Company, setting up a showdown over its future.
articles.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16 — The investor Nelson Peltz won some seats on the board of the H. J. Heinz Company on Wednesday, securing a foothold in the company that may result in a showdown over its direction.
articles.byline: By SEAN D. HAMILL and ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

articles.headline: Lebanon Sends National Army to Patrol South
articles.snippet: Lebanon’s cabinet voted to start deployment on Thursday, but finessed the delicate issue of disarming Hezbollah.
articles.abstract: Lebanon’s cabinet voted to start deployment on Thursday, but finessed the delicate issue of disarming Hezbollah.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Thursday, Aug. 17 — The Lebanese Army moved into the country’s south at dawn on Thursday, a day after the cabinet approved the deployment under a United Nations-mandated cease-fire, but finessed the delicate issue of disarming Hezbollah.
articles.byline: By John Kifner and Robert F. Worth

articles.headline: Singapore Acts as Haven for Stem Cell Research
articles.snippet: Singapore is emerging as a hotbed for stem cell research, thanks to liberal laws in the field and equally liberal government financing.
articles.abstract: Singapore is emerging as a hotbed for stem cell research, thanks to liberal laws in the field and equally liberal government financing.
articles.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE, Aug. 16 — You can’t buy Wrigley’s Spearmint gum in Singapore. But human embryonic stem cells? That’s a different matter.

articles.headline: Bombs Aimed at G.I.’s in Iraq Are Increasing
articles.snippet: The insurgency has strengthened despite the killing of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, according to statistics from the U.S. military in Baghdad.
articles.abstract: The insurgency has strengthened despite the killing of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, according to statistics from the U.S. military in Baghdad.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Michael R. Gordon, Mark Mazzetti and Thom Shanker.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon, Mark Mazzetti and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Overcoming Adoption’s Racial Barriers
articles.snippet: A growing number of white couples are pushing past longtime cultural resistance to adopt black children.
articles.abstract: A growing number of white couples are pushing past longtime cultural resistance to adopt black children.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
articles.byline: By Lynette Clemetson and Ron Nixon

articles.headline: Schoolteacher Arrested in JonBenet Ramsey Case
articles.snippet: The suspect, an American, was arrested in Bangkok in the death of JonBenet Ramsey, the 6-year-old found strangled in 1996.
articles.abstract: The suspect, an American, was arrested in Bangkok in the death of JonBenet Ramsey, the 6-year-old found strangled in 1996.

articles.headline: Old Records Go In, CD's Come Out
articles.snippet: Are you over 30? Sorry to hear it. That makes you part of the Transition Generation, those who have witnessed the world’s shift from analog to digital recordings.
articles.abstract: Are you over 30? Sorry to hear it. That makes you part of the Transition Generation, those who have witnessed the world’s shift from analog to digital recordings.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARE you over 30? Sorry to hear it. That makes you part of the Transition Generation, those who have witnessed the world’s shift from analog to digital recordings. You therefore probably have a collection of phonograph records, audiocassettes and videotapes sitting in a closet somewhere at this very moment.

articles.headline: Parking-Lot Dentistry Is Finding Its Niche
articles.snippet: In the parking lots of 11 casinos in Las Vegas, mobile dental offices combine technology and the American penchant for saving time.
articles.abstract: In the parking lots of 11 casinos in Las Vegas, mobile dental offices combine technology and the American penchant for saving time.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Samantha Taube stepped out of the MGM Grand into the bright sun to walk to the parking lot. After a short distance, she approached a trailer, entered, sat in a dentist’s chair and had her teeth cleaned.

articles.headline: Faces, Too, Are Searched at U.S. Airports
articles.snippet: As the man approached the airport security checkpoint here on Wednesday, he kept picking up and putting down his backpack, touching his fingers to his chin, rubbing some object in his hands and finally reaching for his pack of cigarettes, even tho...
articles.abstract: As the man approached the airport security checkpoint here on Wednesday, he kept picking up and putting down his backpack, touching his fingers to his chin, rubbing some object in his hands and finally reaching for his pack of cigarettes, even though smoking was not allowed.     Two Transportation Security Administration officers stood nearby, nearly motionless and silent, gazing straight at him. Then, with a nod, they moved in, chatting briefly with the man, and then swiftly pulled him aside for an intense search.
articles.lead_paragraph: DULLES, Va., Aug. 16 - As the man approached the airport security checkpoint here on Wednesday, he kept picking up and putting down his backpack, touching his fingers to his chin, rubbing some object in his hands and finally reaching for his pack of cigarettes, even though smoking was not allowed.

articles.headline: Parking-Lot Dentistry Is Finding Its Niche
articles.snippet: Samantha Taube stepped out of the MGM Grand into the bright sun to walk to the parking lot. After a short distance, she approached a trailer, entered, sat in a dentist's chair and had her teeth cleaned.     ''If you know Las Vegas traffic these da...
articles.abstract: Samantha Taube stepped out of the MGM Grand into the bright sun to walk to the parking lot. After a short distance, she approached a trailer, entered, sat in a dentist's chair and had her teeth cleaned.     ''If you know Las Vegas traffic these days, you know what a benefit this is,'' said Ms. Taube, who trains employees in the huge casino's slot machine operations. After 20 minutes, she was back at work.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS - Samantha Taube stepped out of the MGM Grand into the bright sun to walk to the parking lot. After a short distance, she approached a trailer, entered, sat in a dentist's chair and had her teeth cleaned.

articles.headline: Singapore Acts as Haven for Stem Cell Research
articles.snippet: You can't buy Wrigley's Spearmint gum in Singapore. But human embryonic stem cells? That's a different matter.     Last month a local company, ES Cell International, claimed to be the first company to commercially produce human embryonic stem cell...
articles.abstract: You can't buy Wrigley's Spearmint gum in Singapore. But human embryonic stem cells? That's a different matter.     Last month a local company, ES Cell International, claimed to be the first company to commercially produce human embryonic stem cell lines in a way that makes them suitable for clinical trials. Researchers can buy vials of stem cells from ES Cell over the Internet for $6,000.
articles.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE, Aug. 16 - You can't buy Wrigley's Spearmint gum in Singapore. But human embryonic stem cells? That's a different matter.

articles.headline: Lebanon Sends National Army to Patrol South
articles.snippet: The Lebanese Army moved into the country's south at dawn on Thursday, a day after the cabinet approved the deployment under a United Nations-mandated cease-fire, but finessed the delicate issue of disarming Hezbollah.     At several points, soldie...
articles.abstract: The Lebanese Army moved into the country's south at dawn on Thursday, a day after the cabinet approved the deployment under a United Nations-mandated cease-fire, but finessed the delicate issue of disarming Hezbollah.     At several points, soldiers crossed the Litani River, about 15 miles north of the Israeli border, into the long-held separate realm of Hezbollah.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Thursday, Aug. 17 - The Lebanese Army moved into the country's south at dawn on Thursday, a day after the cabinet approved the deployment under a United Nations-mandated cease-fire, but finessed the delicate issue of disarming Hezbollah.
articles.byline: By John Kifner and Robert F. Worth

articles.headline: Eye on Election, Democrats Run as Wal-Mart Foe
articles.snippet: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, a likely Democratic presidential candidate in 2008, delivered a 15-minute, blistering attack to warm applause from Democrats and union organizers here on Wednesday. But Mr. Biden's main target was not Repub...
articles.abstract: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, a likely Democratic presidential candidate in 2008, delivered a 15-minute, blistering attack to warm applause from Democrats and union organizers here on Wednesday. But Mr. Biden's main target was not Republicans in Washington, or even his prospective presidential rivals.     It was Wal-Mart, the nation's largest private employer.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES, Aug. 16 - Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, a likely Democratic presidential candidate in 2008, delivered a 15-minute, blistering attack to warm applause from Democrats and union organizers here on Wednesday. But Mr. Biden's main target was not Republicans in Washington, or even his prospective presidential rivals.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Schoolteacher Arrested in JonBenet Ramsey Case
articles.snippet: An American identified as a schoolteacher was arrested in Bangkok yesterday in the death of JonBenet Ramsey, the 6-year-old beauty pageant princess who was found strangled in her home on Dec. 26, 1996.     The district attorney in Boulder, Colo., ...
articles.abstract: An American identified as a schoolteacher was arrested in Bangkok yesterday in the death of JonBenet Ramsey, the 6-year-old beauty pageant princess who was found strangled in her home on Dec. 26, 1996.     The district attorney in Boulder, Colo., where the Ramseys lived when JonBenet's body was found, said the arrest yesterday came after ''several months of a focused and complex investigation.''
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: Inflation Gives Signs of Slowing
articles.snippet: The government's latest report on consumer prices, issued yesterday, suggests that inflation is slowing.     The overall rise came to a seasonally adjusted 0.4 percent in July, mainly because of a surge in gasoline prices and in the monthly cost o...
articles.abstract: The government's latest report on consumer prices, issued yesterday, suggests that inflation is slowing.     The overall rise came to a seasonally adjusted 0.4 percent in July, mainly because of a surge in gasoline prices and in the monthly cost of renting a home, even as the housing market itself deteriorated.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government's latest report on consumer prices, issued yesterday, suggests that inflation is slowing.

articles.headline: Peltz Is Seen With 2 Seats at Heinz
articles.snippet: The investor Nelson Peltz won some seats on the board of the H. J. Heinz Company on Wednesday, securing a foothold in the company that may result in a showdown over its direction.     The gains by Mr. Peltz, after a vitriolic proxy fight over seve...
articles.abstract: The investor Nelson Peltz won some seats on the board of the H. J. Heinz Company on Wednesday, securing a foothold in the company that may result in a showdown over its direction.     The gains by Mr. Peltz, after a vitriolic proxy fight over several months, represents the latest success for a growing cadre of investors who call themselves shareholder activists and seek to bring about change at companies by publicly challenging them.
articles.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16 - The investor Nelson Peltz won some seats on the board of the H. J. Heinz Company on Wednesday, securing a foothold in the company that may result in a showdown over its direction.
articles.byline: By Sean D. Hamilland Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Overcoming Adoption’s Racial Barriers
articles.snippet: When Martina Brockway and Mike Timble, a white couple in Chicago, decided to adopt a child, Ms. Brockway went to an adoption agency presentation at a black church to make it clear they wanted an African-American baby.      Their biological daughte...
articles.abstract: When Martina Brockway and Mike Timble, a white couple in Chicago, decided to adopt a child, Ms. Brockway went to an adoption agency presentation at a black church to make it clear they wanted an African-American baby.      Their biological daughter, Rumeur, 3, is accumulating black dolls in preparation for her new brother or sister. Black-themed children's books like ''Please, Baby, Please'' by the filmmaker Spike Lee and his wife, Tonya Lewis Lee, share shelf space with Elmo and Dr. Seuss.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
articles.byline: By Lynette Clemetson and Ron Nixon

articles.headline: Bombs Aimed at G.I.’s in Iraq Are Increasing
articles.snippet: The number of roadside bombs planted in Iraq rose in July to the highest monthly total of the war, offering more evidence that the anti-American insurgency has continued to strengthen despite the killing of the terrorist leader Abu Musab al-Zarqaw...
articles.abstract: The number of roadside bombs planted in Iraq rose in July to the highest monthly total of the war, offering more evidence that the anti-American insurgency has continued to strengthen despite the killing of the terrorist leader Abu Musab al-Zarqawi.      Along with a sharp increase in sectarian attacks, the number of daily strikes against American and Iraqi security forces has doubled since January. The deadliest means of attack, roadside bombs, made up much of that increase. In July, of 2,625 explosive devices, 1,666 exploded and 959 were discovered before they went off. In January, 1,454 bombs exploded or were found.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 - The number of roadside bombs planted in Iraq rose in July to the highest monthly total of the war, offering more evidence that the anti-American insurgency has continued to strengthen despite the killing of the terrorist leader Abu Musab al-Zarqawi.
articles.byline: This article is by Michael R. Gordon, Mark Mazzetti and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Old Records Go In, CD's Come Out
articles.snippet: ARE you over 30? Sorry to hear it. That makes you part of the Transition Generation, those who have witnessed the world's shift from analog to digital recordings. You therefore probably have a collection of phonograph records, audiocassettes and v...
articles.abstract: ARE you over 30? Sorry to hear it. That makes you part of the Transition Generation, those who have witnessed the world's shift from analog to digital recordings. You therefore probably have a collection of phonograph records, audiocassettes and videotapes sitting in a closet somewhere at this very moment.     Maybe you still maintain a turntable and cassette deck, which you use to listen to your tunes just as you have for decades. If that's your situation, congratulations; you may skip to the next article.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARE you over 30? Sorry to hear it. That makes you part of the Transition Generation, those who have witnessed the world's shift from analog to digital recordings. You therefore probably have a collection of phonograph records, audiocassettes and videotapes sitting in a closet somewhere at this very moment.
